data.title: Forge Road
data.listingDescription: Forge Road (Tour Stop #9)

images.altText: tour stop #9 with exhibits and parking
images.title: Forge Road
images.caption: The Confederate Breakout

data.bodyText:
On the morning of February 15, 1862, the Confederate divisions of Generals Gideon Pillow and Bushrod Johnson, along with Lieutenant Colonel N.B. Forrest's cavalry, launched an attack on the Union line held by Brigadier General John A. McClernand near this location. This road was known at that time as Forge Road because it led to Randolph Forge.

Soldiers with both the 26th Mississippi and 26th Tennessee infantries, later joined by other regiments, were successful in pushing General McClernand's Division from its position. Soldiers with the 8th, 9th, 11th, 12th, 18th, 20th, 30th, and 41st Illinois Infantries fought valiantly to hold their positions, before they were exhausted and scattered, needing ammunition to continue the fight. 

For a brief time, Forge Road was open, which would have allowed a way of escape for Confederates.  By nightfall, after more than six hours of continuous battle, the Confederates were ordered to return to their original positions. The way of escape was now closed, as Union forces moved to reoccupy the area once more.

The Texas Monument was placed in this location in 1963 to honor of the Texas troops who fought at Fort Donelson.
data.audioDescription: This site sits along a busy city street. One wayside exhibit, two War Department plaques, and one granite monument tell the story of this site. One field cannon sits under an oak tree. Earthworks line the park road, ending at Main Street (to your right near the parking area). The area has a manicured lawn. A small, wood-framed church sits across the street from this location. In the distance from this tour stop, you can see another brick church, private homes, and a city municipal water tower.

data.title: Great Temple Mound Complex
data.listingDescription: Consisting of the two tallest mounds in the park, the Great Temple Mound Complex is where the chief and second-chief would have lived during the Mississippian Period, and offers a beautiful view of the surrounding area from atop the mounds.

images.altText: Two grassy mounds in an open field with the park road running in front of them.
images.title: Great and Lesser Temple Mounds
images.caption: A view of the Great and Lesser Temple Mounds

data.bodyText: The Great Temple Mound Complex consists of the two tallest mounds in the park: The Great Temple Mound and the Lesser Temple Mound. These mounds were created by the Mississippians who lived here in the 10<sup>th</sup> century CE. The flat-topped, pyramidal mounds were raised in layers at intervals over many years; and suggest intricate social relationships. The Great Temple Mound is where the village chief would have lived, and was built in four separate stages with clay steps going up the northern slope. It’s estimated that 10 million baskets of dirt, weighing about 60 pounds each, were used to build the 55-feet-tall mound! Today, there are steps that allow visitors to climb to the top of both mounds for a spectacular view of the surrounding area.
data.audioDescription: Two grass-covered mounds side by side. The taller one on the right is fifty-five feet high, and is the Great Temple Mound. The smaller one on the left, the Lesser Temple Mound, is ten feet high. Wooden steps built by park staff allow visitors to climb to the top of both mounds.

quickFacts.value: Tallest two mounds in the park; where the chief and second-chief lived during the Mississippian Period.
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Jack-O-Lantern Branch Trail
data.listingDescription: A 1.5 mile trail through the forest at Booker T. Washington National Monument. This forest is where Booker T. Washington spent time as an enslaved child away from the owner's house on the Burroughs plantation. In these woods, Booker may have gathered food for his mother, who was the cook for the plantation. He may have fished to help the family supplement the diet they were provided by the owners of the plantation.

images.altText: Jack-O-Lantern Branch Nature Trail
images.title: Jack-O-Lantern Branch Nature Trail
images.caption: 1.5 mile nature trail at Booker T. Washington National Monument

data.bodyText: A 1.5 mile trail through the forest at Booker T. Washington National Monument. This forest is where Booker T. Washington spent time as an enslaved child away from the owner's house on the Burroughs plantation. In these woods, Booker may have gathered food for his mother, who was the cook for the plantation. He may have fished to help the family supplement the diet they were provided by the owners of the plantation.
data.audioDescription: A walk into a 1.5 mile deciduous forest. This trail is not handicapped accessible except for all-terrain wheel chairs.

data.title: Twin Tanks and Arch Rock Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Arch Rock Nature Trailhead and the Twin Tanks Wilderness Backpacking Board.

images.altText: A dirt trail between split rail fences with a backpacking information board surrounded by shrubs.
images.title: Twin Tanks Trailhead
images.caption: Trailhead for the Arch Rock and California Riding and Hiking Trails

data.bodyText: Located along Pinto Basin Road, the Twin Tanks and Arch Rock Nature Trail Trailhead provides access to the California Riding and Hiking Trail as well as the Arch Rock Nature Trail. Arch Rock provides a short 1.4 mile hike to 100 feet elevation gain to an arch while the California Riding and Hiking Trail provides opportunities for longer hikes and wilderness backpacking. Backpackers can self register at the Twin Tanks Wilderness Backpacking Board by the trailhead.
data.audioDescription: The Twin Tanks and Arch Rock Nature Trail Trailhead is located in a wide desert valley. The trail is a dirt path that starts from the south end of a paved parking lot on the west side of Pinto Basin Road. Next to the trailhead is a wilderness backpacking board with information, an area map, and self registration box for backpacking. The area contains scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. Rocky mountains are in the distance in every direction.

data.title: Union Camp

images.altText: exhibit area depicting the Union camp
images.title: Union Camp
images.caption: Exhausted and cold U.S. soldiers camped in this area by nightfall, February 15, 1862

data.bodyText:
In this location, you will see rifle pits, some just beyond the wayside exhibit. These are much different than the other earthworks that surrounded the Confederate fort. This tour stop is called the Union camp, because it was captured after General Smith's counterattack earlier in the day (Tour Stop #5).

Many of General Buckner's men, the soldiers with the 18th Tennessee, the 2nd Kentucky, and the 14th Mississippi infantries, struggled throughout the afternoon on February 15th to try and dislodge the Union forces from their newly-acquired position in the former Confederate rifle pits. By nightfall, soldiers on both side collapsed, cold, exhausted, and hungry. Both armies roughly ended up in the same battlefield positions from which they began fighting earlier that same morning. The Confederates had captured some pieces of artillery, weapons, and military supplies, but this wasn't what this breakout attempt had been all about.

Confederates now formed a new line, their final defense on the wooded ridge, across the park road, behind you.
data.audioDescription: The mowed grass areas contain rifle pits, one wayside exhibit, and parking. The area is heavily wooded along the ravines and areas beyond the earthworks or rifle pits.

data.title: Ryan Ranch Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Trailhead for hiking to Ryan Ranch

data.bodyText: Ryan Ranch Trailhead is located just east of Ryan Campground. This trailhead provides access to Ryan Ranch on an easy one mile hike along an old dirt road with 135 feet of elevation gain.
data.audioDescription: Ryan Ranch Trailhead is in a desert valley bottom with rocky mountains in a every direction. A dirt trail heads south from a small parking area on the south side of Park Boulevard. The area is filled with scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs.

data.title: C&O Canal Lock 5
data.listingDescription: In 1829, President John Quincy Adams laid the cornerstone of Lock #5. Floods damaged the lock in the 19th century, and the upper red sandstone stones were added, probably to avert even more flood damage. The lower, grey-colored stone is original and came from Aquia creek and from a quarry less than 1 mile form this site. Level 4, between Lift Lock 5 and Lift Lock 4 (between Thomas Jefferson St and 31st Street in Georgetown, Washington DC) is four miles long.

images.altText: A lock partially filled with water, next to grass and trees
images.title: Lift Lock 5
images.caption: Lock 5 of the C & O Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText: In 1829, President John Quincy Adams laid the cornerstone of Lock #5. Floods damaged the lock in the 19th century, and the upper red sandstone stones were added, probably to avert even more flood damage. The lower, grey-colored stone is original and came from Aquia creek and from a quarry less than 1 mile form this site. Level 4, between Lift Lock 5 and Lift Lock 4 (between Thomas Jefferson St and 31st Street in Georgetown, Washington DC) is four miles long.
data.audioDescription:
(249 words)
The C&O Canal Lock 5 is located on the west side of Canal Road, NW Washington, DC about eight tenths of a mile north of Chain Bridge Road.
A gravel parking lot, about sixty-feet wide and one hundred-feet long is set immediately off Canal Road and is bordered by gravel at its east entry side.
At the west end of the parking lot a twenty-foot long, six-foot wide wood bridge with railings on both sides carries over the lower gate of Canal Lock 5. A twenty-foot long wood beam angles upward from the southeast side of the lock's lower gate. The beam on the southwest side is broken off at about two feet. Bluestone blocks line the inner walls of the canal lock.
Along the west side of the lock, a cement-paved area rises to the north about four feet along a fifty-foot span to the upper lock gate. The cement section also runs eighty feet to the west where it connects to an Inlet Canal that runs parallel to Lock 5.
The upper gate features two twenty-foot long wood beams that sit atop the lock's wood doors and cross at the center.
Facing south from Lock 5, to the right a second wood bridge across the gravel path, with railings on both sides, carries about forty feet over the Inlet Canal and connects to the south end of the C&O Canal towpath. Water from the inlet canal flows underneath the bridge, then connects to water from Lock 5.
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.title: C&O Canal Lock 6

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText: Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.
data.audioDescription: (119 words) Lock 6 is located along the towpath in Cabin John, MD. It can be accessed from a small parking lot off of the Clara Barton Parkway. From the Lock 6 parking lot, follow the gravel path down the hill approximately 200 feet, passing the lockhouse on your left and the road parallel the path on the right. When the trail turns, stay left, and walk another approximately 50 feet and arrive at the lock. A pedestrian access bridge crosses the lock, with railings along both sides. The dirt towpath is across the lock bridge, with south being to the left and north being to the right. The Lock 6 lockhouse sits just east of the lock. End of Description.

data.listingDescription: Managing water levels both during normal canal operations and during floods was and still is a key task. Water for the canal comes in at series of inlet locks. Inlet Lock 1, which is at Lift Lock 5 over the Washington, DC boundary in Maryland, feeds the Georgetown section. Waste Weirs (a gate in the side of the canal) and the lift lock gates can be used used to adjust levels. There are also spillways along the canal, which are also referred to as "mule drinks" that operate l

images.altText: A paved path sits next to a wooden board walk.
images.title: C & O Canal Mule drink and overflow
images.caption: C & O Canal Mule drink and overflow

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText: Managing water levels both during normal canal operations and during floods was and still is a key task. Water for the canal comes in at series of inlet locks. Inlet Lock 1, which is at Lift Lock 5 over the Washington, DC boundary in Maryland, feeds the Georgetown section. Waste Weirs (a gate in the side of the canal) and the lift lock gates can be used used to adjust levels. There are also spillways along the canal, which are also referred to as "mule drinks" that operate like a dam spillway to let water flow out of canal if it is getting to close to the towpath level. Managing a water canal was challenging in 1850 and still is today.
data.audioDescription:
(179 words)
The C&O Canal Mule drink and overflow is located along the C&O Canal towpath in Washington, DC, about one-half mile south of Mile 2 on the towpath.
At this location the towpath divides. On the east side, the path becomes four-feet wide cement, and declines about one foot. It runs for about seventy-five feet before inclining again back to the level of the gravel towpath. The cement is lined with ridges at the incline and decline points.
On the west side, the path leads to a wood walkway with three-foot high wood rails on both sides. The walkway is supported by seven cement columns that allow for about three feet of space underneath. A one-foot wide cement border lines the east side of the cement path. Further east the ground slopes down slightly about five feet towards the canal.
West of the wooden walkway, the ground underneath is an approximately ten-foot wide strip of cobblestone that appears to run most of the seventy-five-foot length of the walkway. Trees and vegetation cover much of the west side of the path.
END OF DESCRIPTION

There were outtake pipes that were used to blow off steam from the boilers. Early on the morning of September 11, 2016, the Spong family was moored to the concrete wall theat ran beneath the powerhouse, right at a steam pipe. At usual time, 6 am, the powerhouse blew out the boilers and the steam burst and forc

images.altText: Tall green grass sits on the edge on the canal.
images.title: C & O Canal Outtake
images.caption: C & O Canal Outtake

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText: Georgetown was once an industrial area. The building across the canal is the former Capital Traction Powerhouse, which provided power for the streetcars in Georgetown. There were outtake pipes that were used to blow off steam from the boilers. Early on the morning of September 11, 2016, the Spong family was moored to the concrete wall theat ran beneath the powerhouse, right at a steam pipe. At usual time, 6 am, the powerhouse blew out the boilers and the steam burst and forced super hot steam into the cabin of the boat where the children were sleeping. Mrs. Spong tried to save them and was severely scalded. Mr. Spong also rushed to save his children. Tragically, all three children, John (age 13,) Samuel (age 11,) and Sarah (age 6) were fatally injured.
data.audioDescription:
(241 words)
The C&O Canal Outtake is located west of Wisconsin avenue, NW along the C&O Canal in the Georgetown neighborhood in Washington, DC.
From the intersection of M street and Wisconsin avenue NW, travel south on Wisconsin avenue about two hundred seventy-five feet. Turn right, before the bridge overpass, and proceed about one hundred feet through a brick plaza area. A staircase leading down will be on the left. Follow the staircase and turn right at the towpath. Proceed about two hundred feet and you will be at the C&O Canal Outtake.
The canal is overgrown with tall grass at this location. Shallow water gently flows through the grass and reeds. The north side of the canal towpath is bordered by a seventy-foot tall stone wall. Across the canal is the red brick side of a two-story building. Along the bottom of the building is an old stone foundation about three feet tall. Set in the foundation is a round open pipe, about one-foot wide, curved to face downward two feet above the water line. A second opening sits one foot to the left. Ivy grows up the side of the brick building.
To the east, the Wisconsin avenue bridge is visible a few hundred yards away, running about forty feet above. The 31st street bridge sits one block beyond. To the west about two hundred feet, a pedestrian walkway connects to the second-floor level of the brick building across the canal.
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.title: Potomac Aqueduct
data.listingDescription: From 1843 to 1886, coal boats navigated across the Potomac Aqueduct - actually over the Potomac - on their way via the Alexandria Canal to the wharves of Alexandria, about 7 miles south of here. Later, the aqueduct became part of a trolley line from Rosslyn to Georgetown. If you look across the river, you can still see the only remaining pier.

images.title: The Aqueduct along the C&O Canal
images.caption: The Aqueduct along the C&O Canal in Georgetown

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText: From 1843 to 1886, coal boats navigated across the Potomac Aqueduct - actually over the Potomac - on their way via the Alexandria Canal to the wharves of Alexandria, about 7 miles south of here. Later, the aqueduct became part of a trolley line from Rosslyn to Georgetown. If you look across the river, you can still see the only remaining pier.
data.audioDescription:
(191 words)
The Alexandria Aqueduct, also called the Potomac Aqueduct, is located just south of the C&O Canal Towpath in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, DC.
Travel west along the towpath about four hundred feet from the Key Bridge. Turn left and proceed south about one hundred seventy feet and you will be at the top of the aqueduct.
Facing south from this location an open grass and dirt field about one hundred feet wide and sixty feet long leads up to a chain link fence. Beyond the fence is the granite aqueduct structure, two, two hundred-foot spans of bridge about thirty feet apart. In between them is a grass surface about six feet below the top of the bridge spans, which stretches out about fifty feet.
Stairs about seventy feet to the west lead down to Water Street and the lower level of the aqueduct. Two arches of the aqueduct, about fifty feet wide each and constructed with granite blocks, are visible underneath. One carries over the end of Water Street and the trailhead of the Crescent Trail to the west. The second arch runs to the edge of the Potomac River.
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.listingDescription: The spill way is used to let high water in the canal flow back into the Potomac River. The spillway is also known as a "mule drink" as it is a low and convenient place for the canal mules to have a drink of water.

data.audioDescription:
(145 words)
The C&O Canal Spillway is located along the C&O Canal towpath, about fifty feet south from the C&O Canal Mile 4 marker.
The Spillway is a section of the towpath that turns into a flat cement surface, consistent with the width and level of the towpath. The spillway slopes on both sides - towards the canal on the east side, and to the west towards the Potomac River. The Spillway spans about four hundred feet from north to south.
The towpath bows out to a wooden side section to the west and runs beside the cement Spillway. The side walkway is raised by two-foot tall cement pillars below that allow for overflow water from the canal to pass underneath. The walkway also spans about four hundred feet and features three-foot tall wood railings throughout on both sides. Trees line the walkway on its west side.
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.listingDescription: Coal boats navigating the C&O Canal could use the tidelock to lock through between the Potomac River and Rock Creek, The used the last 1/4 of mile of the creek. Canal boats could then be taken nearby wharf or down river to unload at a power plant or warehouse along the Potomac. A dam with a waste gate went across the mouth of Rock Creek and was used to maintain a steady water level in Rock Creek for canal operations instead of having the creek get lower with a low tide. Ther

images.altText: Stone wall with a brick path jutting out into a river.
images.title: Tidelock
images.caption: Tidelock

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText: Coal boats navigating the C&O Canal could use the tidelock to lock through between the Potomac River and Rock Creek, The used the last 1/4 of mile of the creek. Canal boats could then be taken nearby wharf or down river to unload at a power plant or warehouse along the Potomac. A dam with a waste gate went across the mouth of Rock Creek and was used to maintain a steady water level in Rock Creek for canal operations instead of having the creek get lower with a low tide. There was a connector canal to the Washington City Canal that once existed where Constitution Ave is today.
data.audioDescription:
(427 words)
The C&O Canal Tide Lock wayside is located at the end of a peninsula formed by the Potomac River and Rock Creek in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, D.C.
From the intersection of Virginia Avenue and Rock Creek Parkway, NW travel west on Virginia avenue into a parking lot. Continue west through the parking lot, which will turn into a walkway bridge of about ninety feet over Rock Creek. Follow the path about eighty feet, at which point it will turn left. The Potomac River now will be on the right. Continue south and travel two hundred feet, past a cement landing at Thompson Boat Center on the left. Proceed through this area onto a gravel patch and continue another fifty feet. At this point the Potomac River edge will be approaching. Turn left and proceed fifty feet along a two-foot wide gravel path. The wayside will be on your right.
The wayside faces south and is set among the ruins of an old canal lock. A wooden pedestrian bridge is ten feet to the left, and a twenty-foot patch of overgrown grass sits between the sign and the lock ruins.
The three by four-foot sign is a faded light brown. Written across the top brown border is:
Tide Lock and Rock Creek Basin
Text across the top of the image reads:
The 184.5-mile-long Chesapeake and Ohio Canal begins at Tide Lock and ends at Cumberland, Maryland. Here canal boats entered the canal to bypass mountains, swift currents, and shallows. Boats exited Tide Lock into the Potomac River to proceed to downstream ports to off-load cargo.
A 200-foot dam (right side of photo below) crossed the mouth of Rock Creek, creating a basin where canal boats docked and off-loaded cargo.
A photograph covers the entire sign, showing a landscape of a bridge and a structure of wood beams carrying over a creek lined by stone walls. Two men stand with a horse on the left in the foreground. A small white building with one window sits at the end of the bridge, and other buildings can be see lining the background. The creek opens up to a river on the right.
A one by three-inch white map shows the Potomac River curling around the southern tip of Washington, DC.
Text to the left reads:
"Boats from Tide Lock could enter the Potomac River and go downstream to the Washington Branch Canal, where present-day Constitution Avenue is located. A lockhouse building still standing at 17th Street and Constitution Avenue is the only remaining evidence of this branch canal.
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.audioDescription:
(165 words)
The C&O Canal Waste Weir is located along the C&O Canal towpath in Washington, DC, about one-half mile south of Mile 2 on the towpath and about eighty feet south of the C&O Canal mule drink and overflow.
At this location the towpath widens by about three feet and becomes a seventeen-foot long bridge with a wood plank floor. On the east side, six-foot tall cement walls angle out towards the canal. A three-foot tall wood railing guards the side.
A three-foot high rail also lines the west side. A seventeen-foot long wood beam is set in the ground about three feet from the west side of the path, creating a side path. Set atop the wood beam on the ground are three, three-foot tall black iron screws, each about two-inches thick and flat on top. They sit on an iron nut that is affixed to the beam with a metal bracket and bolts.
Trees, vegetation and brush line the west side of the path.
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.title: Fishmarket Square
data.listingDescription: Where's the market? While the current brick plaza was constructed in the 1980s, the history goes back to the 1790s. Before the canal was built, this plaza and the space on the other side of the canal was market and jail. Across the canal is the 1865 Market building, built to replace the 1795 market. After the canal cut the market in two, this portion became a fish market.Surrounding this open area were some of the many mills and other industrial structures that were once an i

images.altText: A red brick plaza, surrounded by a red building, trees, and tables.
images.title: Fish Market Square in Georgetown
images.caption: Fish Market Square in Georgetown

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText:
Where's the market? While the current brick plaza was constructed in the 1980s, the history goes back to the 1790s. Before the canal was built, this plaza and the space on the other side of the canal was market and jail. Across the canal is the 1865 Market building, built to replace the 1795 market. After the canal cut the market in two, this portion became a fish market.

Surrounding this open area were some of the many mills and other industrial structures that were once an important part of Georgetown's economy. You can still see portions of the a few the industrial buildings. The section of Georgetown between the river and M street, including the canal, was once an industrial area. These mills were powered with water from the canal which was another form of income for the canal company.

Currently, the Georgetown Business Improvement District puts out tables and chairs for people to sit and have their lunch.
data.audioDescription:
(314 words)
The Fish Market Square is a plaza along the C&O Canal in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, DC.
From the intersection of K street and Potomac street, NW travel three hundred feet north on Potomac street. The road curves to the right at this point and becomes Grace street. Six brick pillars are lined along the north sidewalk curve as it follows the curve of the road. This is the entrance to the Fish Market Square.
A five-foot wide, sixty-foot long cobblestone path lines the front of the plaza area directly in front of the brick pillars and follows the curve of the road. Each of the pillars stands about five feet tall, two-feet wide, and slope up from the ground along their backsides. The tops are flat and protrude out at their front sides, opposite the sloped back, about two feet beyond the square bases below them.
The plaza area is a wide-open space that runs about one hundred feet from Grace street to the canal, and about two hundred feet across from east to west. Tables and chairs are set in the center, and four trees grow through the plaza along the canal's edge. Lounge chairs and a swinging bench sit beneath the trees, overlooking the canal.
A six-foot wide wood staircase in the northeast corner of the plaza leads over the canal to its north side. At the northwest end the canal towpath continues along the canal to the west. Brick office and condominium buildings sit at both the east and west sides of the plaza.
Set in the middle of the plaza is a two by one-foot blue metal sign that reads:
Welcome to Fishmarket Square
All seating open to the public.
Pull up a chair and:
Call your mom
Avoid your boss
Write a novel
Eat a cookie
Plan for retirement
[Fill in the blank]
Georgetown Business Improvement District
END OF DESCRIPTION

images.title: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal Visitor Center
images.caption: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal Visitor Center

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText:
This building located at 1057 Thomas Jefferson St,. served as the Visitor Center for the C&O Canal National Historical Park from 1992 until 2012. The National Park Service operated a replica canal boat, "The Georgetown" from here between 1982-2011. The tour took visitors on a 60-90 minute mule drawn boat ride up and down the canal.

Prior to 2011, the National Park Service operated replica canal boats tours. Visitors could lock up and down through Lift Lock 4 during its excursions- up and down the canal. On the south side of the lock, the mules would be tethered in a corral, awaiting the time when they would begin pulling the boat.

The National Park Service is working a partner, Georgetown Heritage, to bring replica canal boat tours back to Georgetown.
 

Georgetown and the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal



Georgetown became a port city soon after its 1751 founding. Located on the Potomac River, it was a logical choice for the canal's terminus. Canal activity further spurred Georgetown's economic growth. By the late 1800s, it was a bustling industrial port, with loads of cargo transferring between ocean-going ships, smaller boats, and wagons. On the canal, mule-drawn coal boats sidled up alongside Georgetown's warehouses to unload their freight. After their week-long journey down the 184.5 mile canal, canal families looked forward to the sights and sounds of Georgetown.
Construction of the canal began in 1828. Thousands of men, primarily immigrants, performed the backbreaking, dangerous work of digging and blasting through soil and rock. The skilled laborers, including stonemasons, carpenters, and blacksmiths created the dams, locks, culverts, aqueducts, and the Paw Paw Tunnel. Though each section of the canal started operating as it was completed, the entire route between Cumberland and Georgetown officially opened on October 10, 1850. After years of decreasing profits and devastating floods, operation of the canal ceased in 1924.

Canal Boat Tour - (MAY BE OPERATIONAL IN 2021)



The canal boat tour takes about an hour. On the tour, you will travel through a lock and learn more about the canal, its history, and the people who made a living delivering cargo between Cumberland and Georgetown.
data.audioDescription: (1224 words)The Georgetown ranger contact station is located in downtown Washington, DC in the Georgetown neighborhood, at the northeast intersection of Thomas Jefferson Street, NW and the C&O Canal.The location is a two-story end unit row house, set at the northwest corner of Lock 3 of the C&O Canal. The red-brick building's front door is located on Thomas Jefferson Street. Four brick steps lead up to the white painted front door. An alcove with three windows is on the right, and three windows line the second floor.The visitor entrance is located on the southern, canal side. Two swinging glass windows are above on the first floor, and a single window sits on the top level. Four other windows and a door with an iron gate are set along the south side. A two by four-foot brown sign sits on the south, canal side that reads: "Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historic Park." The visitor entrance is set in a ten square foot alcove area lined with a two-foot high wood ledge bench. To the right of the door is a glass sign featuring Georgetown Visitor Center information. Along the northern side of this area are three white signs, about six feet tall set from ground level.The left sign features on its top third a brown and white picture of an industrial waterfront. Smokestacks and iron riggings are visible from across a wide river.The bottom of the sign features a timeline which spans all three signs. This portion covers 1825 to 1865. Noted at the top is "1828 Ground Broken for Canal" and "1861-65 Civil War."The below are three photographs. The left picture, beneath the year 1825, shows men with horses on a wide and barren dirt landscape. Text above them reads:The canal was initially envisioned by its supported as a trade route between east and west. However, by the time the canal reached Cumberland, plans to extend it to the Ohio River at Pittsburgh had been abandoned for financial reasons.The middle picture, beneath the year 1850, shows a horse drawn carriage next to a railroad track in a dirt trench along a river above. A white house sits at the river's edge and smoke billows from machinery along the riverbank to the left. Text above reads.The canal was most active and profitable between 1865 and 1900. Over five hundred boats carried nearly one million tons of cargo annually between Cumberland and Georgetown. More than 90% of the boats arrived in Georgetown filled with coal.The final picture of the right shows an image of a canal crowded with nine canal boats sitting in the water. Text above them reads:The canal stretched 184.5 miles between Georgetown and Cumberland. Rising 605 feet in elevation along the journey, the canal averaged 60 feet across, six feet deep, and included seven dams, 11 aqueducts, and 74 lift locks.The middle sign is titled at the top:The Canal through GeorgetownBelow is map showing the canal as it passes from Rock Creek on the right, across the sign to the Aqueduct and Key Bridge on the left. The map shows locks one through four on the right side, and an arrow indicates your location between locks three and four. A dark blue line indicates the canal, and a brown line laid next to it shows the towpath.The bottom third of the sign is a continuation of a timeline that runs through all three signs. Represented here are:1890 B&O Railroad Takes Over Canal1914-18 World War 11924 Floods Close CanalThree black and white pictures line the bottom of the sign. Furthest left, below the year 1875, is an image of a canal, full of water and lined with four story brick row houses and buildings. A building with two tall smokestacks sits along the canal's right side. Text above reads:Georgetown grew to accommodate the canal's business. New wharves supported the distribution of coal, stone, and timber. Flour, paper, and cotton milling became successful industries in the town, using the canal as a new source of water power.The middle picture, under the year 1900, shows a canal scene crowded with canal boats lined up in the water. A man sits on the boat in the left foreground, and two girls stand along the towpath on the right. Text above reads:The Georgetown section of the canal includes four locks. As boats approached Georgetown and lined up to unload cargo, they created traffic jams on the canal. Boat crews sometimes waited days to unload before they could begin the return trip.The right-side picture, under the year 1925, shows a man in overalls and boots turned and facing away as he stands atop a boat in a canal. A boy and girl are at his sides, also facing away. He holds their hands as they float down the canal. Text above reads:Canal families eagerly anticipated their arrival in Georgetown. After a week on the boat, traveling through rural country and small towns, parents would allow their children to go up the city's streets to buy candy, ice cream or see a movie.The right sign has along its top third a black and white image of a man in hat and suspenders walking along a canal towpath with three horses t

data.bodyText: Waysides provide safety information and orientation.
data.audioDescription:
(621 words)
The C&O Canal Lock 5 Parking Lot is located on the west side of Canal Road, NW Washington, DC about one-eighth of a mile north of Chain Bridge Road.
The parking lot is a gravel space, about sixty-feet wide and one hundred-feet long. The lot is set immediately off Canal Road and is bordered by gravel at its east entry side.
Two portable bathrooms sit at the northeast end of the lot, on the right as you enter from Canal Road, about twenty feet from the roadside.
The lot is all gravel and surrounded by trees, including three thirty-foot tall trees located at the south end. A picnic table sits beneath them.
As you travel west a three-sided four by three-foot wayside sits at the trailhead in front of the canal and a ten-foot wood bridge that carries over it. The south side is titled at the top: River Warnings! Text below warns about various hazards associated with the Potomac River:
River Warnings!
The Potomac River is a hazardous force that deserves our constant respect. The 22-mile section of the river from Georgetown to Seneca has four dangerous areas that are unsafe for any type of water related recreation including boating, canoeing, fishbone, swimming, wading or rock hopping. Do not enter the water. This warning applies to the river areas around the Washington Aqueduct Dam, Great Falls, Little Falls Dam, and Little Falls Rapids. Serious and often fatal accidents occur at these locations every year.
A map to the right identifies areas too dangerous to enter the river and to avoid. These are Washington Aqueduct Dam, Great Falls, Little Falls Dam, and Little Falls Rapids:
Washington Aqueduct Dam:
A water supply dam for Washington, D.C. located just above the Great Falls. If this hazardous dam doesn't stop you, the falls just below it will! The Great Falls, MD parking lot is the last take-out before the dam.
Great Falls:
Where the Potomac River drops 40 feet over a steep jagged rock wall and into a narrow gorge. The falls are impassible. Use the C&O Canal to bypass the dam. You can reenter the river at Rocky Cove below the falls.
Little Falls of the Potomac
Located just upstream from Chain Bridge, this narrow chute of extremely powerful currents is hazardous. Many boaters and fishermen have drowned here. Take your boat out along the canal in the immediate vicinity of Sycamore Island. You can reenter the river at Fletchers Boat House.
Little Falls Dam:
Located four miles downstream from Cabin John Bridge, this innocent-looking small vertical drop is deadly. The river flowing over the dam is recycled back toward the dam wall rather than downstream. Trapping any object including people in the backwash. Many who end up in this vicious backwash drown. Stay away! The last take-out before the dam is the C&O Canal in the immediate vicinity of Sycamore Island.
The east-facing side of the sign is a map titled at the top to read:
C&O Canal National Historical Park - Locks 1 through 25
The map shows the C&O Canal in blue, flowing down from Cumberland, MD, around the edge of Washington, DC to Thompson's Boat Center in Georgetown where it enters into the Potomac River. A boxed map to the right identifies C&O Canal National Historic Parks, the C&O Canal, and Canal locks 1-25 from Cumberland to Georgetown.
The third side of the sign is titled "Lock 5", and shows general information about the C&O Canal, including safety warnings to wear life jackets at all times when boating, rafting, or tubing, a message that pets must be leashed, ice skate at your own risk, fishing licenses are required, canal boat rides are available, and information is available online at www.canaltrust.org.
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.bodyText: Waysides provide safety information and orientation.
data.audioDescription:
(350 words)
The Fletcher's Boathouse comfort station is located on the C&O Canal in Washington, D.C., east of Fletcher's Boat House.
From the intersection of Canal and Reservoir Roads, NW travel north on Canal Road about one hundred fifty feet, then turn onto the far-left lane side road, to the left of a three-foot tall stone dividing wall. The three-story white Abner Cloud House will be on your left.
Follow the gravel path to the left around the corner of the house, where a parking lot runs along the house and about one hundred yards to the south.
At the north end of the parking lot a ten-foot wide bridge carries over the C&O Canal to the west. A short trail leads about thirty feet north to restrooms and a water fountain. Set at the turnoff to the bridge are three wayside signs, each about four by three feet.
The sign furthest left is titled at the top: River Warnings! Text below warns about various hazards associated with the Potomac River: [LINK]
The sign in the middle is a map titled at the top to read:
C&O Canal National Historical Park - Locks 1 through 25
The map shows the C&O Canal in blue, flowing down from Cumberland, MD, around the edge of Washington, DC to Thompson's Boat Center in Georgetown where it enters into the Potomac River. A boxed map to the right identifies C&O Canal National Historic Parks, the C&O Canal, and Canal locks 1-25 from Cumberland to Georgetown.
The third sign is titled across the top: "Fletchers Cove." The sign features a map showing your location at the south end of the C&O Canal and Potomac River. It also provides warning information that pets must be leashed, ice skate at your own risk, and boaters, rafters, and tubers must wear life jackets at all times. Other information details fishing license, boat rides and other visitor information.
A two by one-foot white sign to the right reads:
C&O Canal Trust and Friends of Fletchers Cove ae working together to restore the Cove and you can help!
Learn more - Get involved
CanalTrust.org/Fletchers
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.title: Brandy Creek Boat Launch
data.listingDescription: Brandy Creek Boat Launch and picnic area is located near Brandy Creek Beach, Brandy Creek RV and Dry Creek Group camping areas all of which are on the south side of Whiskeytown Lake. The launch area has a large parking lot designed to accommodate vehicles with boat trailers, accessible rest rooms as well as an adjacent picnic area that is right on the water. Boat moorage and dry storage are also available here.

images.altText: Brandy Creek Boat Launch
images.title: Brandy Creek Boat Launch
images.caption: Brandy Creek Boat Launch

data.bodyText:
Brandy Creek Marina, boat launch and picnic area is located near Brandy Creek Beach, Brandy Creek RV and Dry Creek Group camping areas all of which are on the south side of Whiskeytown Lake. The launch area has a large parking lot designed to accommodate vehicles with boat trailers, accessible rest rooms as well as an adjacent picnic area that is right on the water. Boat moorage and dry storage are also available at this location by arrangement with our partner Whiskeytown Marinas LLC.

Brandy Creek Boat Launch is a good option on busy summer weekends when the other boat launches may become crowded as it tends to be slightly less utilized and has a very large parking area. Whether you are heading out for a day on the lake to fish or to just enjoy being out on the water it is a great option for launching your kayak, paddleboard, or boat. Other boat launches are located at the Whiskey Creek Boat Launch and Oak Bottom Boat Launch areas.

Access to the boat launch area can be made by turning on J. F. Kennedy Memorial Drive from Highway 299 at the Visitor Center and then proceeding across the dam, and continuing past the entrance to Brandy Creek Beach until you see the sign for Brandy Creek Boat Launch.

data.title: Dry Tortugas Research Natural Area (RNA)
data.listingDescription: The RNA is a 46 square-mile no-take ecological preserve that provides a sanctuary for species affected by fishing and loss of habitat.
data.bodyText: The Dry Tortugas Research Natural Area (RNA) was established in 2007 to create a new layer of protection for the marine resources of Dry Tortugas National Park. The RNA is a 46-square-mile no-take ecological preserve that provides a sanctuary for species affected by fishing and loss of habitat in this region of the Gulf of Mexico. Anchoring and fishing are prohibited within the RNA boundaries of Dry Tortugas. Approved activities include boating, swimming, snorkeling, scuba diving, research, and education.

data.title: Junior Officer's Quarters
data.listingDescription: The Junior Officers Quarters, Buildings 5 and 6, situated on the southern corner of the Green were built under Superintendent J.G. Benton. The Junior Officers Quarters were built in the Second Empire Style with many architectural elements that reflected the Victorian Period influence, which was departure from the classical architecture, giving the South Green a unique look. The duplex provided housing to the officers and their families who came to work at Springfield Armory.

images.altText: A red brick building with a covered porch and a rear ell on a sunny day during late fall.
images.title: Junior Officers Quarters 5 and 6
images.caption: The Junior Officers Quarters built under Superintendent J.G. Benton.

data.bodyText:
Situated on the southern corner of the Green, atop a hill overlooking the city of Springfield, sits the Junior Officers Quarters (Buildings 5 and 6).

Superintendent J.G. Benton submitted a request for funds for the Junior Officers Quarters in 1867, which was denied. Two years later in March of 1869, he submitted new plans and estimates which were approved. The plans this time, included the duplex design incase as Benton stated, if there was ever a need for another officer at the Armory, along with a new location on the old fire engine site (old guard house) on the southern corner of the Green. The estimated cost for the buildings was around $15,000. 

In 1869 the construction of the duplex began with the masonry structure completed in 1870. The Junior Officers Quarters was built in the Second Empire Style with many architectural elements that reflected the Victorian Period influence, a departure from the classical architecture that was used in many of the other Hill Shops. This departure gives the Junior Officers Quarters and the southern corner of the Green a distinctive look and feel. 

The duplex was built with utilities that were typical for the time which included gas lighting, plumbing, copper boilers to heat water, and hot-air furnaces! With multiple stories, modern utilities and elaborate interior design elements, the building provided much comfort to the officers and their families. Even with all the modernization, people were still traveling by horse! Along the road is an elevated brown stone step that allowed residents and visitors to easily jump onto their horse or step into their carriage. 

As new families moved in and there was new leadership at the Armory, the Junior Officers Quarters underwent many renovations that included enlarging the parlors, added windows, the addition of a one-story ell and a two-story addition to Quarters 5. By the close of the Armory, the quarters that were built identical were completely different reflecting the needs and desires of the various occupants. 

The Junior Officers Quarters were listed in the Massachusetts Most Endangered Historic Resources and in 2017 the building underwent major restoration including rebuilding portions of the foundation and historic chimneys as well as repointing the brickwork. 

In 1960, it was designated as a contributing building to the Springfield Armory National Historic Landmark and is registered in the National Historic Register of Historic Landmarks. With the close of the Armory in 1968, the building ownership was transferred to the State of Massachusetts to Springfield Technical Community College. Today while the building is not occupied, it still brings to remembrance the activity and families of the Armory.
data.audioDescription: A three story red brick building with a one story extension to the rear, a covered porch on the front and a brownstone foundation. There are numerous arched windows with white framing and brownstone lintels and sills. The front porch has two doors, one leading into each duplex and two large floor length windows. The double pitched roof is made of black and grey slate with four chimneys on the main building and one the rear extension. Around the porch, windows and roof there is intricate carved white scroll work.

quickFacts.value: Springfield Armory was established as the Nation’s First Federal Arsenal. The Armory was a leader in the development of interchangeability, the technological innovations of firearms, the mechanization and specialization in precision manufacturing, and the production of small arms. Springfield Armory had numerous cultural, geographic and economic impacts on the City of Springfield and surrounding communities. The Junior Officers Quarters became a defining feature of the Springfield Armory Complex.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: The Junior Officers Quarters is a contributing building to the Springfield Armory National Historic Site which is registered as a National Historic Landmark.
quickFacts.name: Designation

data.title: Birds of South Marble: Tufted Puffin
data.listingDescription: Tufted puffins are a highlight of any visit to coastal Alaska. They dig burrows in the grassy hillsides of South Marble Island in Glacier Bay.

images.altText: A tufted puffin swimming in dark green water
images.title: Tufted Puffin Swimming
images.caption: A tufted puffin swims in the waters of Glacier Bay.

data.bodyText:
Tufted Puffin, Fratercula cirrhata

 
Mature tufted tufted puffins of both sexes have white cheeks, orange feet and bill, black belly, and distinctive yellow feather plumes curling down the back of the head and neck. They nest in colonies, their large bills used for excavating borrows in which they lay one egg. Immature and non-breeding adults are all dark, the tip of their bills and feet are a pale orange. Heavy bodied for their wing size, puffins beat their wings upwards of 400x a minute to keep airborne.
 

Measurements
Wingspan Length Weight
25" 15" 1.7 lbs/620 g






Know before you go: South Marble Island is closed to camping and foot traffic year-round. All vessels (including kayaks) must remain further than 50 yards from the southern half of South Marble Island and remain further than 100 yards from nesting seabird colonies. Binoculars are advised.

data.title: Tour Stop #2: The Battle Line

images.altText: Monuments along Battleline Road
images.title: Monuments along Battleline Road
images.caption: A carriage of visitors travels along Battleline Road.

data.bodyText: The line of US monuments extending the length of Battleline Road mark where US troops constructed crude breastworks during the early morning hours of September 20. Secure in their positions, they successfully halted repeated Confederate assaults.
data.audioDescription: You are now standing among US monuments to the United States Regular Infantry, which fought here during the Battle of Chickamauga.

data.title: Tour Stop #5: Viniard Field

images.altText: The gravestone of Tabler Viniard
images.title: Tabler Viniard Gravestone
images.caption: Tabler Viniard's final resting place is in the Chattanooga National Cemetery

data.bodyText:
Step back one day to September 19. Thousands of soldiers, one division at a time, fought back and forth across this field trying to gain control of LaFayette Road. When sunset came, neither side held the road, yet thousands had paid the ultimate sacrifice. 

Tabler Viniard, the father of the family who owned and farmed the land surrounding this tour stop, enlisted in the 1st Georgia Infantry, US. Unfortunately, he passed away in 1864, while stationed in North Alabama. He is buried in the Chattanooga National Cemetery.
data.audioDescription: You are now standing along LaFayette Road, surrounded by fields and trees. Dotting the landscape are numerous monuments commemorating the struggle that occurred at the Vinidard Farm.

data.title: Tour Stop #6: Lightning Strikes

images.altText: John Munson, a member of Wilder's Brigade, sits on a horse and is holding a Spencer rifle
images.title: Private John Munson - 72nd Indiana
images.caption: Pvt. John Munson of the 72nd Indiana Mounted Infantry astride his mount holding his Spencer rifle.

data.bodyText: US Colonel John T. Wilder's brigade of mounted infantry, armed with Spencer repeating rifles, halted a portion of the attacking Confederates. The "Lightning Brigade" had the only US success on this part of the Battlefield.
data.audioDescription: You are now standing at the Wilder Brigade Monument, which is open seasonally for you to climb the circular staircase inside to get a bird's-eye view of this portion of Chickamauga Battlefield.

data.title: Tour Stop #7: Rout of the Union Right

images.altText: The wounding of General Hood
images.title: The Wounding of General John B. Hood
images.caption: Confederate General John B. Hood was wounded just north and east of Tour Stop #7.

data.bodyText: Confederate soldiers swept out of the woods and into the fiels in what one commander called "a scene of unsurpassed grandeur." This attack collapsed the US right, forcing the defenders, including US General Rosecrans, to flee.
data.audioDescription: You are currently standing in a large, open field through which the Confederates attacked US soldiers on prominent rise to the west.

data.title: 15-inch Rodman Cannon

images.altText: A very large black cannon
images.title: 15 Inch Rodman
images.caption: One of Fort Foote's two original 15-inch Rodman cannons on a reconstructed base

data.bodyText:
The sheer immensity of the two Rodman guns at Fort Foote made them objects of curiosity wehn they were first brought to the Fort. Visitors frequently came to see them. The 15-inch Rodmans weigh about 49,000 pounds, and required 300 to 400 soldiers to move them up the bluff from river to fort. The balls fired by the smooth-bore Rodmans weigh 500 to 600 pounds and took about fifty pounds of black powder, a type of gunpowder.

It was a special occasion each time the big guns were fired. On February 27, 1864, three shots were fired from the 15-inch Rodman. Crowds of visitors beheld the occasion. Again, on April 1, 1864, a large party from Washington came to witness the workings of the big guns. The Rodman was fired at a 25-degree elevation at a range of three miles. Because the guns put off an intense concussive force, it was noted that observers would raise their toes and open their mouths to lessen the effects.
The cannon closest to the river is of particular importance. Engraved on its 15-inch muzzle is 'No. 1' and the initials 'TJR'. The 'No 1' is in reference to the fact that this cannon was the first produced by Cyrus Alger and Company. The initials are of the individual who inspected the gun, in this case Brigadier General Thomas J. Rodman who also designed the weapon.
data.audioDescription: Spaced about 70 yards apart two massive cannons point out over the water. Each cannon is roughly 12 ft long and is mounted on a large metal base which raises it to about 15 ft high. The barrel of the cannon is 15 in in diameter. Both Canon and base are painted black. This rests on a half circle mounts made of stone and metal.

data.title: Root Glacier
data.listingDescription: Of the 5,000 square miles of glacial ice in Wrangell-St. Elias, the Root Glacier is the most accessible. A moderate 1 ½ mile walk from the historic mining town of Kennecott along the Root Glacier Trail leads you onto the glacier. Be aware that glaciers can be dangerous. It is recommended to wear crampons or ice spikes on your shoes and go with an experienced guide.

images.altText: Root Glacier
images.title: Root Glacier
images.caption: Root Glacier

relatedParks.fullName: Wrangell - St Elias National Park & Preserve
relatedParks.name: Wrangell - St Elias

tags: wrangell st elias national park and preserve
data.bodyText:
Of the 5,000 square miles of glacial ice in Wrangell-St. Elias, the Root Glacier is the most accessible. A moderate 1 ½ mile walk from the historic mining town of Kennecott along the Root Glacier Trail leads you onto the glacier. Be aware that glaciers can be dangerous. It is recommended to wear crampons or ice spikes on your shoes and go with an experienced guide. 

Trailhead
Latitude: 61.487114 Longitude: -142.890863

Access: Trail departs from Kennecott Mill Town. You can access Kennecott from McCarthy - walk the road between McCarthy and Kennecott (an extra 4.5 miles), take the commercial shuttle, or ride a bike. This trail does NOT access the Erie Mine.

Distance: 4 miles round-trip from Kennecott to the glacier or 8 miles round-trip to the Erie Mine tram cables.

Time: 2-6 hours round-trip (hiking duration).

Maps: USGS Maps, McCarthy 1:250,000, McCarthy (B-6), (C-6) 1:63,360

Difficulty: Easy to Moderate. Terrain is relatively level with moderate elevation gain and loss.

Highlights: Glacier viewing, mining artifacts, views of Mt. Blackburn, Regal Mountain, and Donaho Peak. Route: From the Kennecott Visitor Center, walk through the Kennecott Mill Town, north towards the Root Glacier. About a half-mile beyond the visitor center, the road will split. Stay straight. (The right hand trail leads to Jumbo and Bonanza Mines.) The trail will soon cross over Bonanza Creek and Jumbo Creek and then wind its way through the lateral moraines of the Kennicott and Root Glaciers. Approximately 1.5 miles after leaving Kennecott, the trail reaches the Root Glacier access trail. (Primitive campsites, along with an outhouse and food lockers, are available in this area.) To access the glacier, turn left at the sign and follow the trail as it winds down the moraine to the toe of the glacier. This trail crosses Amazon Creek, which is a seasonal stream. Depending on recent rainfall or spring melt, you may need to cross this stream.

Hazards: The Root Glacier can be very slippery and dangerous. Crampons are strongly recommended. Avoid walking along the edge of Root Glacier as rotting ice and swift, cold water are potentially dangerous. Bears are present along the entire route. For maximum safety, travel in groups, be noisy when you are walking, and never give any food to a bear.

Notes: If you are camping at the Jumbo Creek Camping Area or Donaho Basin, it is required that your food is stored in the bear-resistant food boxes or your own Bear Resistant Food Container (BRFC).
data.audioDescription: Hike on a glacier. Caution use crampons and go with an experienced guide. 4 miles, 2-4 hours round-trip. Trailhead at Kennecott mill town, 5 miles north of McCarthy.

data.title: South Marble Island - Bird Tour Introduction
data.listingDescription: Learn the birds that call South Marble Island home in Glacier Bay National Park.

images.altText: A side view of a glaucous winged gull
images.title: Glaucous-winged gull in Glacier Bay
images.caption: The glaucous-winged gull is a aerial staple of Glacier Bay, seen throughout the park.

data.bodyText:
Welcome to your self guided tour: The Birds of South Marble Island!

 
A highlight of any trip into the bay is the variety birds readily seen. A slow cruise past South Marble Island offers the opportunity to see many species of birds at once. The island provides nesting habitat for some, while also providing space for birds to rest between feeding excursions. Here are a few of the birds to look out for at South Marble Island and elsewhere in the bay.


Know before you go: South Marble Island is closed to camping and foot traffic year-round. All vessels (including kayaks) must remain further than 50 yards from the southern half of South Marble Island and remain further than 100 yards from nesting seabird colonies. Binoculars are advised.

data.title: Little Falls Branch
data.listingDescription: Little Falls Branch drains from Maryland and Washington DC and flows under C&O Canal into the Potomac River at Little Falls rapids. The rapids mark the upstream end of the tidal Potomac. In the 1800's, a dam diverted water from the stream into the reservoirs that supplied the District Of Columbia with water. When the Washington Aqueduct was built, the dams were removed. Streams like the Little Falls Branch, flow under the canal through culverts. There are approximately 180 cu

images.altText: A creek runs through thick foliage beside a trail.
images.title: Little Falls Branch
images.caption: Little Falls Branch

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText: Little Falls Branch drains from Maryland and Washington DC and flows under C&O Canal into the Potomac River at Little Falls rapids. The rapids mark the upstream end of the tidal Potomac. In the 1800's, a dam diverted water from the stream into the reservoirs that supplied the District Of Columbia with water. When the Washington Aqueduct was built, the dams were removed. Streams like the Little Falls Branch, flow under the canal through culverts. There are approximately 180 culverts along the 184.5 miles of canal.
data.audioDescription:
(123 words)
Little Falls Branch is located along the western side of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Towpath, about eight-tens of a mile north of Chain Bridge Road.
From C&O Canal Lock 5, travel south on the C&O Canal Towpath about four hundred eighty yards. The canal flows parallel to the towpath on its eastern side. To the west a creek flows away from the canal and towpath, through lush forest towards the Potomac River.
A dirt trail runs alongside the creek on its south side. About twenty feet down the trail, a tunnel is visible back to the east which allows the water to run under the towpath. The thin trail continues west through the woods and toward the Potomac River, through rocky terrain.
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.title: Low water intake

images.altText: Water runs in the C&O canal.
images.title: Low Water Intake on the C & O Canal
images.caption: Low Water Intake on the C & O Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText: Low Water Intake on the C&O Canal
data.audioDescription:
(377 words)
The Low water intake is accessed from a path off the C&O Canal towpath in Washington, D.C. Travel north about four-tens of a mile on the towpath from the Chain Bridge overpass. A gravel path will be on the left. Just north along the left side of the towpath, will be two red and white signs.
The sign on the left is about three by three feet tall and written across a red border in white letters reads: "Danger." Below on a white panel, with translations in Spanish and Vietnamese reads:
Extremely strong current/undertow
Stay off rocks at river's edge
No swimming or wading
The right sign reads in red letters, with Spanish translation below:
Trash Free Park
The gravel trail becomes a twenty-foot wide cement paved road after about ten feet and descends slightly into the forest. At about one hundred yards large jagged boulders begin to line the left side of the trail. Twenty feet further there is a ten-foot tall stone and rock wall that lines the right side as well. Low water, about one-inch deep flows slowly on the path to the west towards the Potomac River.
Continuing west, the tall forest trees lessen. The path stays in a straight line and becomes more open, though still lined by rock on both sides. Some trees and vegetation hang over the high rock sides.
After about two hundred yards into the path, it turns to the right and rises slightly up a five-foot ramp into a cement plaza area. The cement runs about one hundred feet north to south and eighty feet east to west. At the south west corner of the plaza are four cement steps with cement railings on both sides that lead to another platform area.
The twenty by forty-foot rectangular space is surrounded by a three-foot high, one-foot thick cement wall. It sits along the east edge of the Potomac River as water rushes by from right to left. A ten-foot buffer of rock and large boulders lines the area between the plaza and river.
Lush forest trees fill the western hillside across the river and three large mansions sit along the top. To the south about three hundred yards along the river the Chain Bridge spans east to west.
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.title: Birds of South Marble: Horned Puffin
data.listingDescription: The horned puffin is a slightly less common puffin found in the summer months in Glacier Bay.

images.altText: Side view of swimming horned puffin
images.title: Horned Puffin swims in Glacier Bay
images.caption: Horned puffins are excellent swimmers, potentially diving 250 feet deep for prey.

data.bodyText:
Horned Puffin, Fratercula corniculata

 
Unlike their tufted cousins, horned puffins have chests and white bellies. The "horns" are black fleshy spikes above each eye. Puffin bills function like pipe wrenches, opening wide to allow them to carry many fish at one time. The bills of immature and non-breeders birds are dark, as are their check patches, but their bellies are always white. These puffins do not dig borrows, but nest on cliffs. As with all seabirds, both sexes help raise their one chick.
 

Measurements
Wingspan Length Weight
23" 15" 1.4 lbs/620 g






Know before you go: South Marble Island is closed to camping and foot traffic year-round. All vessels (including kayaks) must remain further than 50 yards from the southern half of South Marble Island and remain further than 100 yards from nesting seabird colonies. Binoculars are advised.

data.title: Birds of South Marble: Pelagic Cormorant
data.listingDescription: Pelagic cormorants are often seen with wings stretched far apart, drying them in the sun. Looking closely at their black feathers, a beautiful iridescence can occasionally be seen. These birds migrate to Glacier Bay each summer.

images.altText: A sheer black pelagic cormorant swims in smooth reflective water.
images.title: Pelagic Cormorant
images.caption: On sunny days, look for iridescent colors in the cormorant's black feathers.

data.bodyText:
Pelagic Cormorant, Phalacrocorax pelagicus


All dark with a metallic iridescence, breeding adults of both sexes grow crests on top of their head and at the nape, and show white flanks. These fish-eaters swim to locate prey, then dive propelled by their feet while steering with their wings. They build pedestal nests of grasses and seaweed cemented together by guano, and tend to reuse nests year after year. They lay 2-5 eggs; young have sooty-gray feathers. / If the bird you are looking at has orange skin around the base of the bill and chin you are looking at a double-crested cormorant, P. auritus, seen occasionally near SMI. White crests on head may not be erect.

 

Measurements
Wingspan Length Weight
39" 28" 3.9 lbs/1800 g






Know before you go: South Marble Island is closed to camping and foot traffic year-round. All vessels (including kayaks) must remain further than 50 yards from the southern half of South Marble Island and remain further than 100 yards from nesting seabird colonies. Binoculars are advised.

data.title: Birds of South Marble: Pigeon Guillemot
data.listingDescription: Pigeon guillemots are black and white birds with vivid red/orange feet. They flock to Glacier Bay in large numbers each migration season.

images.altText: 3 pigeon guillemots swimming in dark turquoise water.
images.title: Three Pigeon Guillemots
images.caption: Look for the pigeon guillemot's vivid red-orange feet as they swim.

data.bodyText:
Pigeon Guillemot, Cepphus columba

 
In breeding plumage, these dark brown-black birds sport distinct white wing patches. Their feet are bright red, as is the inside of their mouths. Like many seabirds, PGs only come to land to breed, nesting in rock crevices. They are good divers using their broad rounded wings to "fly" underwater. Non-breeding adults and immatures look very different, with much white and mottled feathers, respectively.
 

Measurements
Wingspan Length Weight
23" 13.5" 1.1 lbs/490 g






Know before you go: South Marble Island is closed to camping and foot traffic year-round. All vessels (including kayaks) must remain further than 50 yards from the southern half of South Marble Island and remain further than 100 yards from nesting seabird colonies. Binoculars are advised.

data.title: Birds of South Marble: Black-legged Kittiwake
data.listingDescription: black-legged kittiwakes migrate to Glacier Bay each summer to nest and breed.

images.altText: Several black-legged kittiwakes on cliffside nests. Many pairs face each other face on.
images.title: Black-legged Kittiwakes nesting
images.caption: Black-legged kittiwakes nest on steep rocky cliffs.

data.bodyText:
Black-legged Kittiwake, Rissa Tridactyla

 
You'll know these smaller gulls by their black legs, yellow bill, and all-black wing tips that look like they have been dipped in black ink. They nest in colonies on narrow rock ledges on SMI, as well as other places in the bay; laying 1 -3 eggs. Immature kittiwakes have distinctive "M-shaped" black markings on their wings, a black collar behind their heads and black bills. Their name comes from their call, a repeated, "Kitti-wake, kitti-wake, kitti-wake!"
 

Measurements
Wingspan Length Weight
36" 17" 14 oz/400 g






Know before you go: South Marble Island is closed to camping and foot traffic year-round. All vessels (including kayaks) must remain further than 50 yards from the southern half of South Marble Island and remain further than 100 yards from nesting seabird colonies. Binoculars are advised.

data.title: Birds of South Marble: Common Murre
data.listingDescription: Common murres are often seen on South Marble Island in Glacier Bay National Park in the summertime.

images.altText: Several pairs of common murres on a smooth rocky cliff face.
images.title: Common Murres in Glacier Bay
images.caption: Common Murres are often seen on the cliffs of South Marble Island

data.bodyText:
Common Murre, Uria aalge


These large seabirds have chocolate brown backs, heads and bills, and white bellies. They can dive to 500 feet pursuing fish and invertebrates. Colonial breeders, they nest on crowded rocky ledges and lay one egg. Mottled with a pattern recognized by the parents, eggs have one pointed end; thus, can roll in a tight circle rather than off ledges.

 

Measurements
Wingspan Length Weight
26" 17.5" 2.2 lbs/990 g






Know before you go: South Marble Island is closed to camping and foot traffic year-round. All vessels (including kayaks) must remain further than 50 yards from the southern half of South Marble Island and remain further than 100 yards from nesting seabird colonies. Binoculars are advised.

data.title: Birds of South Marble: Glaucous-winged Gull
data.listingDescription: The glaucous-winged gull is a year-round occupant of Glacier Bay.

images.altText: glaucous-winged gull perched on a floating chunk of ice
images.title: Glaucous-Winged Gull on ice
images.caption: Glaucous-winged gulls are graceful fliers and are often seen perched on icebergs or boat railings.

data.bodyText:
Glaucous-winged Gull, Larus glaucescens

 
These large gulls nest together on more level ground of South Marble Island. "Glaucous" means gray, referring to the backs of their wings. They nest on the ground, typically laying 3 eggs. A red dot near the tip of their large yellow beak provides a target for young hungry chicks to peck to initiate feeding. The large fluffy gray chicks walking near nests in mid-to-late summer will need four years to reach breeding age and achieve adult plumage.

Measurements
Wingspan Length Weight
58" 26" 2.2 lbs/1000 g






Know before you go: South Marble Island is closed to camping and foot traffic year-round. All vessels (including kayaks) must remain further than 50 yards from the southern half of South Marble Island and remain further than 100 yards from nesting seabird colonies. Binoculars are advised.

data.listingDescription: These ruins are the remnants of a once bustling foundry. Nothing remains of foundry building itself, however these walls ruins of outbuildings. The Foxhall-Columbia Foundry was active from 1800-1854. It supplied cannon to the US Army and from 1800-1809 was the exclusive supplier of cannon. In the early years, the foundry was very productive and successful, however by the 1840's it had fallen in prominence.This the namesake of Foundry Branch, a creek which is just upstream of

images.title: Foundry ruins along the C & O Canal
images.caption: Foundry ruins along the C & O Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

data.bodyText:
These ruins are the remnants of a once bustling foundry. Nothing remains of foundry building itself, however these walls ruins of outbuildings. The Foxhall-Columbia Foundry was active from 1800-1854. It supplied cannon to the US Army and from 1800-1809 was the exclusive supplier of cannon. In the early years, the foundry was very productive and successful, however by the 1840's it had fallen in prominence.

This the namesake of Foundry Branch, a creek which is just upstream of the site.
data.audioDescription:
(133 words)
The Foundry Ruins are located on the Crescent Trail, a pedestrian and bicycle path about one third of a mile north of the trailhead at the Whitehurst Freeway overpass in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, D.C.
At this location along the Crescent Trail, a decaying gray stone wall, about ten feet tall, lines the hillside about twenty feet off the path's east side. Covered by overgrowth and vegetation, much of the wall is hidden during the spring and summer months. The wall spans about two hundred feet and is strewn with loose rocks and rubble in some areas.
On the west side of the path sits a brown wooden sign with yellow lettering that reads:
Capital Crescent Trail
Mile 10
A white line is painted around the wood post that holds the sign.
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.title: Counterscarp Gallery

images.altText: A brick structure with a slate roof. The arched doorway is partially blocked by wooden planks
images.title: Counterscarp gallery
images.caption: The counterscarp gallery under the weight of a fallen tree

data.bodyText:
Enemy soldiers landing at Piscataway Creek would need to contend with this position. In what is basically a bunker, defending soldiers could direct small arms, like rifles, towards an approaching foe. If enemy troops managed to breach the outer defenses, fire could also be reversed and directed towards the outer lying dry moat. 

The Counterscarp Gallery is in poor condition. Please exercise caution around the site.
data.audioDescription: The Counterscarp Gallery is an L- shaped defensive structure that is approximately 50 feet in length, and is made up of red bricks and stone with a black slate shingled roof. The interior of the L-shaped structure is hollow on the inside resembling a tunnel, and was used as a reinforced firing position for the rear defenses of Fort Washington.

data.title: Eagle Pass Trailhead (6K1)
data.listingDescription:
This is a remote trailhead at the southeast boundary of the park that is not accessible by road. From this trailhead, you can embark on the following trail within the park:
- Mountain Creek Trail
data.bodyText:
